1_15ecbplus.0: Lindsay Lohan Check Into Betty Ford After Fleeing Other Rehab Facility
1_15ecbplus.2: After leaving rehab in Newport Beach, Calif. , less than an hour after checking in on Thursday, Lindsay Lohan admitted herself to the Betty Ford Center, according to TMZ. com.
1_15ecbplus.3: Her lawyer negotiated with court officials to change the venue of her 90 - day treatment, and the actress traveled to nearby Rancho Mirage to register as a patient.
1_15ecbplus.4: The actress spent time at the Betty Ford Center in 2010; however, a member of the staff ended up suing her for assault.

16_10ecbplus.2: A Norwalk Superior Court judge on Thursday upheld a jury's recommendation that convicted cop killer Jose Luis Orozco die for his crimes.
16_10ecbplus.3: Judge Philip Hickok told a packed courtroom that he weighed all the aggravating factors and mitigating circumstances in the ambush slaying of Los Angeles County Sheriff's Deputy Jerry Ortiz in June 2005, and he concluded that the case "absolutely warrants death instead of life without parole. "
16_10ecbplus.4: Orozco was convicted March 20 of first - degree murder for the slaying of Ortiz, a 15 - year veteran and member of the anti - gang detail at the Sheriff's Lakewood Station.
16_10ecbplus.5: A jury recommended on April 3 that Orozco be executed.
16_10ecbplus.6: Wearing the orange Los Angeles County Jail - issued jumpsuit and with his handcuffed wrists chained to his waist, Orozco smiled as he was led from the courtroom for the last time and turned to make an obscene gesture at a photographer.
16_10ecbplus.7: In denying an automatic motion by the defense to reduce the jury's recommendation from death to life in prison without the possibility of parole, Hickok called the slaying of the newlywed deputy and father of two "a cold - blooded, vicious murder. "
16_10ecbplus.9: Hickok said the aggravating factors in the case were "colossal. "
16_10ecbplus.10: He noted the 29 - year - old gang member not only killed the deputy while hiding outside of the lawman's view behind a door, Orozco also allegedly tried to kill another man just a few days earlier by shooting that individual in the back twice, and had bragged about killing the officer.
16_10ecbplus.11: He had also boasted prior to Ortiz's killing that he wanted to kill a cop, that he wanted to make a name for his gang, the judge added.
16_10ecbplus.12: "The murder was committed without regard in front of two extremely impressionable and young girls, " Hickok said, referring to the star witnesses in the case, two sisters - 8 - and 10 - year - old girls - who described the shooting for the jury.
16_10ecbplus.13: " ( Orozco ) arranged to have witnesses, including those two very young girls, killed so that they would not testify, " Hickok said.
16_10ecbplus.14: Dozens of deputies - many in uniform - packed the court for Thursday's sentencing, just as they had every day of the trial.
16_10ecbplus.15: In the center of the gallery was the slain deputy's wife, Chela Ortiz, who linked hands with her mother - in - law, Rosa Ortiz, and her husband's siblings.
16_10ecbplus.16: Chela spoke briefly before Hickok made the final ruling, addressing her husband's killer directly as she read from a letter written by her stepson, Jeremy Ortiz, and then made her own statement.
16_10ecbplus.18: Why did you have to stand behind a door like a coward? " the young widow read from the teen's letter.
16_10ecbplus.19: Chela Ortiz, who married the deputy three weeks before he was murdered, told Orozco in a firm voice, "I want you to know you did not break our family, " as her family began to cry.
16_10ecbplus.20: "Our Jerry is in heaven, we will see him again. ..
16_10ecbplus.21: his memory will live on, " she said amid the sounds of soft sobs and sniffles.
16_10ecbplus.22: "And you will always be remembered as a coward. "
16_10ecbplus.23: The 35 - year - old deputy was killed on June 24, while investigating an attack in which Orozco shot a man in the back while doing yard work at a Hawaiian Gardens home four days earlier.
16_10ecbplus.24: Along with murder, Orozco was convicted of one count of attempted murder involving the earlier shooting and two counts of possession of a firearm by a felon.
16_10ecbplus.25: Jurors also found true the special circumstance allegations of murder of a peace officer, murder while lying in wait and murder to avoid arrest, along with the allegations that he personally discharged a handgun and committed the crimes for the benefit of a criminal street gang.
16_10ecbplus.26: In addition to asking the judge to reduce the sentence Thursday, Orozco's attorneys made a motion for a new trial, arguing that the DA was wrongly allowed to bring in overwhelmingly prejudicial material about Orozco's gang ties.
16_10ecbplus.27: The attorneys also argued that the defense was hamstrung when the judge refused to let them bring in the Rev. Gregory Boyle to testify on his gang experience in the penalty phase of the trial.
16_10ecbplus.28: They said the judge also refused to let them add jury instructions about others who could be guilty of aiding and abetting Orozco.
16_10ecbplus.29: Prosecutors pointed out all those arguments had been made during the guilt or penalty phase of the trial, and the judge had already ruled in the matters.
16_10ecbplus.30: Hickok agreed and denied both motions.
16_10ecbplus.32: Outside court, Defense Attorney Stanley Perlo said his client stands little chance at winning an appeal in the state Supreme Court, which he described as "very pro death. "
16_10ecbplus.33: In the Ninth District Court of Appeals, there is a chance they will see that the defense was denied a key witness in the penalty phase of the trial, he said.
16_10ecbplus.34: Neither Perlo nor his co - counsel, Robin Yanes, ever claimed their client's innocence.
16_10ecbplus.35: Their client had committed the crimes, both attorneys said Thursday.
16_10ecbplus.36: Rather, they argued that the defendant's lifetime of gang membership and drug abuse were mitigating factors that could not be ignored and that should have spared him death.
16_10ecbplus.37: They added that many of the people called to testify against their client were equally responsible for the deputy's slaying and yet were not prosecuted.
16_10ecbplus.38: "It's a tragic situation with nothing but a sad ending.
16_10ecbplus.39: What else could it be? " Yanes said.
16_10ecbplus.40: Asked about the pending appeal, Deputy District Attorney Phil Stirling said such cases can never be predicted, but added that he and Lowell Anger - the lead DA on the case - were confident the conviction and sentence would stand.
16_10ecbplus.41: After the sentencing, Stirling called Orozco a "predator. "
16_10ecbplus.43: He murdered Deputy Sheriff Jerry Ortiz, in addition to attempting to murder at least three other people that we know of, " Stirling said.
16_10ecbplus.44: Orozco's death sentence will be automatically appealed to the California Supreme Court and he was ordered to be transferred within 10 days from county jail to San Quentin State Prison, where he will await his appeal on death row.
16_10ecbplus.45: "He'll probably live a much longer, healthier life on death row than he would have on the streets, " Perlo said.

31_10ecbplus.0: McDermott fuels Bluejays in Valley tournament win
31_10ecbplus.1: Doug McDermott got a scoring record Friday, Will Artino got a chance to showcase his skills on the big stage and Gregory Echenique got mad.
31_10ecbplus.2: The first two factored heavily into Creighton ’ s 65 - 53 victory against Drake in the quarterfinals of the Missouri Valley Conference tournament, but the last one might have been the deciding factor in moving the Bluejays along to Saturday ’ s semifinals.
31_10ecbplus.3: Echenique scored all 11 points of his points in the second half, grabbed 11 rebounds and blocked six shots.
31_10ecbplus.4: Six of his points, five of his rebounds and five of the blocks came after Echenique got roughed up — tackled, he said — while cutting toward the basket midway through the second half.
31_10ecbplus.5: No foul was called, but Drake might have wished one had been.
31_10ecbplus.6: After the no - call, the 6 - foot - 9, 260 - pound Echenique turned up the intensity to fuel a 15 - 2 run that turned a 47 - 44 Creighton lead into a 16 - point cushion.
31_10ecbplus.7: “ It made me kind of mad when that happened, ” Echenique said.
31_10ecbplus.8: “ It changed my attitude a little, and gave me a little more of an edge.
31_10ecbplus.9: I had to find a way to get that anger out, and I couldn ’ t say anything to the ref and risk getting a technical or something.
31_10ecbplus.10: “ I think I did the right thing, and it kind of capped my focus.
31_10ecbplus.12: With Echenique leading the late charge, Creighton finally subdued a stubborn Bulldog team that was playing to extend its season in an atmosphere that resembled a Bluejays home game.
31_10ecbplus.13: Creighton fans filled almost two - thirds of the 9, 000 seats in the lower bowl of the Scottrade Center, and experienced some anxious moments before their team finally took command.
31_10ecbplus.14: McDermott, Artino and Echenique figured heavily into the outcome that improved the Bluejays to 25 - 7 and advanced them to a 1: 35 p. m. semifinal meeting against Indiana State, which defeated Evansville 51 - 50 in Friday ’ s second quarterfinal.
31_10ecbplus.15: “ Will was great the first half and made some great plays in the second half, ” Creighton coach Greg McDermott said.
31_10ecbplus.16: “ Doug was consistent offensively throughout, and I thought Gregory really changed the game defensively in the second half.
31_10ecbplus.17: “ There was nothing that happened in the paint because of his energy and his ability to block some shots and change shots.
31_10ecbplus.18: And he went and got the basketball off the boards. ”
31_10ecbplus.19: Doug McDermott finished with 23 points, setting the school scoring record when he got his 11th point on a free throw with 4: 43 left in the first half.
31_10ecbplus.20: He made 8 of 14 shots from the field, including 3 of 4 3 - pointers, and grabbed seven rebounds.
31_10ecbplus.21: Artino, whose role has grown as his productivity has increased during the second half of the season, had a career - high 14 points and six rebounds.
31_10ecbplus.22: Five of his points came in a 7 - 0 run in the first half that turned a 12 - 12 tie into a lead Creighton never relinquished.
31_10ecbplus.23: Still, things were getting tight when Drake, which had defeated Bradley in Thursday ’ s play - in round, closed to 47 - 44 on Seth VanDeest ’ s basket with 10: 03 to play.
31_10ecbplus.24: On their next possession, the 15 - 17 Bulldogs missed an open 3 - pointer that would have tied the game.
31_10ecbplus.25: In between, Echenique found himself sprawled on the court after getting bumped hard as he moved toward the basket on a pick - and - roll play.
31_10ecbplus.26: He stayed down for several seconds, then glared at a referee as he got to his feet.
31_10ecbplus.27: Echenique turned into an aggressive force in the final 10 minutes.
31_10ecbplus.28: “ We are a totally different team, ” Greg McDermott said when asked what a fired - up Echenique means to his club.
31_10ecbplus.29: “ We don ’ t resemble the team that we are when he isn ’ t playing like that.
31_10ecbplus.31: He made multiple plays on several possessions.
31_10ecbplus.32: “ I ’ m really proud of him, because sometimes it ’ s hard to get the switch flipped.
31_10ecbplus.33: When it gets flipped, he ’ s hard to deal with. ”
31_10ecbplus.34: Echenique ’ s dunk and free throw after being fouled started Creighton ’ s decisive run, putting the Bluejays ahead 50 - 44.
31_10ecbplus.35: A VanDeest layup would cut the Bulldogs ’ deficit to four, but they wouldn ’ t score again for almost eight minutes while Creighton stretched its lead to 62 - 46.
31_10ecbplus.36: “ You have to know how to use it when you get mad, ” Echenique said.
31_10ecbplus.37: “ I think I used it the right way out there today. ”
31_10ecbplus.38: His teammates know the Bluejays are a different team when Echenique is engaged, one reason Doug McDermott pulled him aside at halftime.
31_10ecbplus.39: Echenique had missed both of his shots in the first 20 minutes and, McDermott said, appeared to be down on himself.
31_10ecbplus.40: “ I just told him, ‘ Greg, you have to be the man here, ’   ” Doug said.
31_10ecbplus.41: “ I told him he was going to be our guy and we were going to feed him the ball.
31_10ecbplus.42: He took that to heart and played with a command.
31_10ecbplus.43: “ I ’ m proud of him, and hopefully he can continue to bring that night after night. ”
31_10ecbplus.44: Echenique scored five of Creighton ’ s first eight points in the second half.
31_10ecbplus.45: Artino then had four in row as Creighton opened its first 10 - point lead of the game before Drake countered with a 9 - 2 spurt that got the Bulldogs back with three points.
31_10ecbplus.46: Echenique “ was definitely a big factor, ” said VanDeest, who had 13 points.
31_10ecbplus.47: “ He has a huge body and uses his body around the basket.
31_10ecbplus.48: He really stepped up in the second half. ”
31_10ecbplus.50: “ Look at his numbers, ” Phelps said.
31_10ecbplus.51: “ He had 11 and 11, and had six blocks.
31_10ecbplus.54: His 14 points bettered his career high of 13.
31_10ecbplus.55: He was two rebounds off his personal best, and his play, especially in the first half, gave Creighton a huge boost.
31_10ecbplus.56: “ Will was tremendous, ” Doug McDermott said.
31_10ecbplus.57: “ He ’ s so easy to play with because he can see over the defense, he ’ s good at the high - low pass and he crashes the boards every time.
31_10ecbplus.58: It ’ s great to have a guy like Will on the team. ”
31_10ecbplus.59: It goes without saying that it ’ s pretty valuable to have McDermott around, too.
31_10ecbplus.60: He came in needing 11 points to break Rodney Buford ’ s scoring record of 2, 106.
31_10ecbplus.61: McDermott had 10 points in the first 7 ½ minutes, then broke the record when he made the first of two free throws with 4: 43 left in the half.
31_10ecbplus.62: McDermott now has 2, 029 points in 106 games as a Bluejay, but who ’ s counting?
31_10ecbplus.63: “ It ’ s a special feeling that I can ’ t explain to pass guys like Kyle Korver, guys I looked up to in my childhood, ” he said.
31_10ecbplus.64: “ And to do it in front of a big crowd here in St. Louis is cool.
31_10ecbplus.65: “ But I don ’ t even think about that stuff.
31_10ecbplus.66: You guys are going to make the most of it, but I ’ m just out there trying to win and play hard every night. ”

13_14ecbplus.2: Methinks somebody's milk just went sour.
13_14ecbplus.4: A 57 - year - old Wasilla woman has been indicted by a federal grand jury on charges she defrauded the state of Alaska and lied to the U. S. Department of Agriculture during the operation of the now - defunct Matanuska Creamery.
13_14ecbplus.5: The indictment also charges Valley Dairy CEO and investor Karen B. Olson with concealing the alleged criminal conduct of the former dairy manager, Kyle Beus.
13_14ecbplus.6: A grand jury in December indicted Beus on charges he misused federal grant money, and he awaits trial.
13_14ecbplus.7: The charges against Olson allege she fraudulently obtained a $430, 000 state agriculture department loan to keep the Valley Dairy afloat by concealing its finances.
13_14ecbplus.8: The indictment also said she submitted false documents to convince the USDA in 2008 to waive its prohibition on using dairy and ice cream - making equipment at Valley Dairy as collateral on state loans.
13_14ecbplus.9: The equipment was purchased in 2007 using federal grants that didn ’ t allow the equipment to be sold or encumbered without special authorization from the USDA.
13_14ecbplus.11: By the mid - 1980s, Mat Maid was faltering, and a state - run corporation took over management.
13_14ecbplus.12: It struggled until Sarah Palin became Alaska's governor.
13_14ecbplus.13: She arrived on the scene shortly before the state Board of Agriculture and Conservation, which had watched the dairy bleed cash for years, voted to deny it further loans.
13_14ecbplus.14: With that move threatening to kill the dairy, Palin fired the board and appointed another, which voted to give the dairy more money.
13_14ecbplus.15: That went on until the new board realized, as did the old board, the dairy just couldn't compete in the real world of modern - day Alaska with cheaper milk shipped in from the Lower 48.
13_14ecbplus.16: Enter Beus, then a Valley dairy farmer, and Bob Havemeister, another dairy farmer.
13_14ecbplus.17: They formed a joint venture to take over the equipment and operations of Mat Maid in an effort to keep it alive.
13_14ecbplus.18: Beus was the one who eventually ended up with most of the equipment and set up a company called Klondike Creamery and Candy, which briefly marketed ice cream in Alaska.
13_14ecbplus.19: It was not long, however, before it was rolled into Valley Dairy - - a joint effort of Beus, Robert Wells and Olson.
13_14ecbplus.20: Olson was the former Alaska state executive director of the U. S. Department of Agriculture Farm Service Agency, a job she held from 1993 to 2001.
13_14ecbplus.21: Olson has insisted in a number of interviews with Alaska Dispatch that the only interest she ever had was trying to keep the dairy business alive in Alaska.
13_14ecbplus.22: After she joined Beus at Valley Dairy, the company began efforts to tap a $5 - million pool of USDA money set aside for rural development.
13_14ecbplus.23: Beus was indicted last year on charges he took at least $120, 000 of that money for his own "personal and discretionary use. "
13_14ecbplus.24: Where and when Olson learned of his alleged activities is not explained in the indictment against her, but it says she devised a scheme "to conceal the true nature of the Valley Dairy finances and the fraudulent activity of Beus, and to obtain a loan from the ARLF ( Alaska Revolving Loan Fund ) to keep the Valley Dairy, of which Olson was an investor and employee, operating. "
13_14ecbplus.25: As many of you undoubtedly know there was a rather suspicious fire that burned the old Matanuska Maid Creamery to the ground.
13_14ecbplus.27: If you are new to this particular Palin scandal there is no better place to catch up then over at Andrew Halcro's now defunct blog.
13_14ecbplus.28: Now some are suggesting that THIS might finally be the straw that snaps the back of Palin's uncanny ability to avoid incarceration.
13_14ecbplus.29: However I would not count my eggs TOO quickly, because while it seems that Olsen has every reason to reduce her sentence by ratting out her old boss, Palin has somehow slipped through the grasping fingers of the Feds a few times before.
13_14ecbplus.30: So let's stay tuned and see how this plays itself out.

28_9ecbplus.0: Nixon Aide Fred LaRue Dies at 75
28_9ecbplus.2: Fred LaRue, a high - ranking Nixon administration official who served a prison term for his role in Watergate and was among those rumored to be Deep Throat, has died.
28_9ecbplus.4: His body was discovered Tuesday by a maid who entered his hotel room in Biloxi, Coroner Gary Hargrove said.
28_9ecbplus.5: The coroner said he believes LaRue died Saturday of natural causes.
28_9ecbplus.6: LaRue was known as the "bagman" who delivered payoffs to keep participants in the Watergate break - in quiet, and served 4� months in federal prison for conspiracy to obstruct justice.
28_9ecbplus.7: LaRue served as special assistant to John Mitchell, the former attorney general who later headed President Nixon's Committee to Re - elect the President.
28_9ecbplus.8: LaRue was present at a 1972 meeting with Mitchell and Nixon aide Jeb Stuart Magruder at Nixon's vacation home in Key Biscayne, Fla. , where the plan to break in Democratic headquarters at the Watergate complex in Washington allegedly was hatched.
28_9ecbplus.9: LaRue said he advised against the burglary.
28_9ecbplus.10: LaRue discounted rumors that he was Deep Throat, saying the mysterious source for Washington Post reporters Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein on the Watergate story was probably a combination of several people.
28_9ecbplus.11: Woodward says Deep Throat was an individual and not a composite, and promised to reveal his identity only after the source is dead.
28_9ecbplus.12: Among the other people who have been cited as possible Deep Throats are Earl J. Silbert, an original Watergate prosecutor; Alexander Haig, who was Nixon's chief of staff and Ronald Reagan's secretary of state; L. Patrick Gray, the acting FBI director who lived four blocks from Woodward; and deputy White House counsel Fred Fielding.
28_9ecbplus.14: After his political career ended in scandal, LaRue returned to his home state of Mississippi to work in his family's oil company and with its real estate holdings.
28_9ecbplus.15: In an interview last summer with The Sun Herald newspaper, LaRue said Magruder lied when he claimed President Nixon knew about the break - in.
28_9ecbplus.16: Magruder claimed Nixon approved the plan in a telephone conversation with Mitchell.
28_9ecbplus.17: LaRue believed no such conversation occurred, saying he screened all the telephone calls on the getaway to Key Biscayne.
28_9ecbplus.19: I don't recall any phone call.
28_9ecbplus.20: I don't think there was one, " he said.
28_9ecbplus.21: If the president had approved the plan, LaRue believes that Mitchell would have told him.
28_9ecbplus.22: "There's absolutely no way, because of my unique relationship with John and Martha Mitchell, that he would not have told me that when I was in Key Biscayne, " LaRue said.
28_9ecbplus.24: I had dinner with the Mitchells four or five times a week.
28_9ecbplus.25: It was not just a political relationship.
28_9ecbplus.26: It was a very personal relationship. "

8_11ecbplus.1: Greece's parliament is due to vote on the hefty cuts and reforms proposed by the government to address the country's financial crisis.
8_11ecbplus.2: It comes a day after three bank workers died in a petrol bomb attack as demonstrations over the planned austerity measures turned violent.

38_5ecbplus.3: An earthquake with a preliminary magnitude of 4. 6 was recorded in the North Bay this morning, according to the U. S. Geological Survey.
38_5ecbplus.4: The quake occurred at 2: 09 a. m. about 14 miles north - northeast of Healdsburg and had a depth of 1. 2 miles.

44_1ecbplus.0: HP Acquires EYP Mission Critical Facilities
44_1ecbplus.2: HP has signed a definitive agreement to acquire EYP Mission Critical Facilities Inc. ( EYP MCF ), one of the leading data center design and engineering firms.
44_1ecbplus.3: HP said the acquisition will help its customers equip their data centers for improved energy efficiency and high - density environments.
44_1ecbplus.4: Financial terms of the transaction were not disclosed.
44_1ecbplus.5: EYP MCF is headquartered in New York and has approximately 350 employees with 13 offices in the United States and the U. K.
44_1ecbplus.6: The company has designed hundreds of technology - intensive mission critical facilities.
44_1ecbplus.7: EYP MCF ’ s expertise in green data center design and energy efficiency was a driver in the deal, as it aligns with HP ’ s extensive power and cooling solutions, such as Dynamic Smart Cooling.
44_1ecbplus.8: “ The data center is the foundation of IT for enterprises, an essential building block for driving business growth and adapting to changing business objectives, ” said John McCain, senior vice president and general manager, HP Services.
44_1ecbplus.9: “ Acquiring EYP Mission Critical Facilities boosts HP ’ s ability to help customers transform their data centers and build dynamic computing environments from the ground up. ”
44_1ecbplus.10: “ Worldwide data center requirements are rapidly growing, with significant year - over - year increases in power consumption, which is fueling demand for energy - efficient power and cooling strategies, ” said Peter Gross, chief executive officer of EYP MCF.
44_1ecbplus.11: “ HP and EYP Mission Critical Facilities will drive innovation by integrating IT infrastructure into the planning and design of the data center, enabling the customer ’ s whole organization to be more energy efficient and adaptive. ”
44_1ecbplus.12: EYP staff are familiar to many in the industry for their presentations at conferences.
44_1ecbplus.13: Gross has spoke often on the advantages of DC power distribution in data centers, while Richard Sawyer has given well - received presentations on managing risk from the emergency power off ( EPO ) button.
44_1ecbplus.14: The deal is subject to certain closing conditions and is expected to be completed within HP ’ s first fiscal quarter.

16_9ecbplus.2: A convicted cop killer laughed Tuesday after hearing a jury's ruling that he be put to death.
16_9ecbplus.3: Jose Luis Orozco showed almost no emotion throughout the three - week trial in which he was convicted of the 2005 murder of Los Angeles County Sheriff's Deputy Jerry Ortiz.
16_9ecbplus.4: A rare exception for the 29 - year - old Hawaiian Gardens gang member was an occasional smile for his mother when he turned in his chair to glance back at her from time to time.
16_9ecbplus.6: When the jury convicted him last month of the deputy's slaying, as well as the attempted murder of another man just a few days prior to the ambush killing of Ortiz, Orozco sat staring straight ahead, unflinching.
16_9ecbplus.7: As Court Clerk Dan Fallon read the jury's sentence shortly before noon Tuesday, several members of the slain lawman's family gasped, clutching one another's hands.
16_9ecbplus.8: At the same time, a small smile spread across Orozco's face and he chuckled.
16_9ecbplus.9: "We understand and we appreciate the gravity of the decision that the jury had to make. .. , and that it took a lot for them to ( come to that decision ), " Chela Ortiz, the deputy's wife, said afterward.
16_9ecbplus.10: "We appreciate everything they did, we know they were very careful. .. and gave this a lot of their attention. "
16_9ecbplus.11: Chela Ortiz - who was married three weeks before her husband was murdered - sat with her mother in - law, Rosa Ortiz, and the rest of the family every day of the trial.
16_9ecbplus.12: They were accompanied by dozens of sheriff's deputies and other family friends, including the family's priest.
16_9ecbplus.13: Most days were difficult and filled with tears as they listened to chilling testimony recounting the last few minutes of Ortiz's life and saw, for the first time, the crime scene and autopsy photos.
16_9ecbplus.14: "I think, for all of us, it was kind of reliving the nightmare all over, " Chela Ortiz said.
16_9ecbplus.15: Family members listened to testimony that included the defendant's violent past and the many times he escaped prosecution by using his gang's influence and power to intimidate victims - including two nearly killed when they were shot and stabbed in the back by Orozco, according to prosecutors.
16_9ecbplus.16: Orozco's friends and fellow gang members also recalled his boasting about killing a cop one day.
16_9ecbplus.17: "I just say thank God it is over, " the deputy's mother, Rosa Ortiz, said.
16_9ecbplus.19: to me it was too hard. "
16_9ecbplus.20: It took the jury of six men and six women a little more than four hours, spread over two days, to choose death over life in prison without the possibility of parole.
16_9ecbplus.21: It was almost the same amount of time used to come to the guilty verdict on March 20.
16_9ecbplus.22: According to three jurors who spoke briefly outside the courtroom, the decision was a difficult one made slightly easier by the thorough job of the prosecutors and investigators.
16_9ecbplus.23: None of them wanted to be identified because of the gang ties to the case.
16_9ecbplus.24: The physical evidence, which including Orozco's DNA and fingerprints found on the murder weapon, was overwhelming, they said.
16_9ecbplus.25: There were also a number of eye witnesses including two girls who described for the jury how Orozco hid behind their front door and shot the deputy as Ortiz spoke with their mother.
16_9ecbplus.26: Equally as damning, jurors said, was the complete lack of remorse shown by the defendant.
16_9ecbplus.27: He squandered two opportunities to turn his life around, including chances to relocate out of state and away from the gang with his family in Las Vegas and again with a friend and former gang member in Florida, they said.
16_9ecbplus.28: It looked to them as though he preferred the life of a criminal and reveled in the notoriety he earned in the deputy's death.
16_9ecbplus.29: A taped conversation between Orozco and two friends - one a fellow gang member and the other an associate - in a holding cell at the Bellflower Courthouse made it clear to the jury that a life in prison would not diminish his threat to society, they said.
16_9ecbplus.30: In that tape, Orozco is heard talking about destroying evidence and ordering a hit on the two little girls and their mother - the star witnesses in the case.
16_9ecbplus.31: "I had to hear that tape again, " one juror said.
16_9ecbplus.32: "Because if we were going to send him to jail for life, he could run the same business from behind bars, " a second juror added.
16_9ecbplus.33: "This way he can't harm anyone anymore. "
16_9ecbplus.35: Ortiz was assigned to track Orozco down the day before his June 24, 2005 murder.
16_9ecbplus.36: That task stemmed from the June 20, 2005 shooting of a black man who - according to prosecutors - Orozco tried to kill simply because of his race.
16_9ecbplus.37: The 15 - year veteran, who learned the day before that he had made the rank of detective, was patrolling in Hawaiian Gardens near 223rd Street when he spotted Orozco and tried to stop him.
16_9ecbplus.38: The gang member took off running with Ortiz behind him, according to court testimony.
16_9ecbplus.39: Ortiz followed Orozco to an apartment complex in the 12500 block of East 223rd Street, to the home of one of Orozco's friends whom the deputy knew from previous altercations, at about 3: 30 p. m.
16_9ecbplus.40: What Ortiz didn't know was that Orozco was lurking behind the woman's front door.
16_9ecbplus.41: As Ortiz spoke to her and reholstered his weapon, Orozco steadied his hand while two of the woman's children - girls age 6 and 8 - and several of her friends looked on.
16_9ecbplus.42: He fired just one shot from his. 38 - caliber revolver, with the slug passing through a crack in the door and hitting the deputy in the side of the head.
16_9ecbplus.43: The 35 - year - old newlywed and father to two boys died almost immediately.
16_9ecbplus.45: Stan Perlo, one of two court - appointed defense attorneys assigned to Orozco, said the defendant's lack of support from his family dealt a massive blow to their case.
16_9ecbplus.46: Originally, Orozco's mother was to take the stand to tell her son's story and talk about the many problems he faced growing up, Perlo said.
16_9ecbplus.47: But she became nervous, telling her son the night before she was to testify that she did not want to go through with it, Perlo explained.
16_9ecbplus.48: Orozco agreed not to force his mother to have to take the witness stand, a decision that likely destroyed his chance at any mercy on the part of the jury, he said.
16_9ecbplus.49: "Our problem was we had no one to tell his story, " Perlo said.
16_9ecbplus.50: "We were counting on his mom and. .. she was too nervous to testify. "
16_9ecbplus.51: Perlo and co - counsel Robin Yanes approached Orozco's case from a somewhat unorthodox position.
16_9ecbplus.52: Rather than argue their client's innocence, they repeatedly referred to their client as the gunman in the presence of the jury and focused on a number of other people they claimed were equally responsible in the crime.
16_9ecbplus.53: It was a tactical decision reached by the two veteran attorneys, both with extensive experience with death penalty cases, and after consultation with their peers, Perlo explained.
16_9ecbplus.54: "We made a lot of decisions that some lawyers would disagree with, " he said.
16_9ecbplus.55: "I would add, personally, a lot of lawyers with a lot less experience. "
16_9ecbplus.57: When Orozco returns to court on May 3, Perlo and Yanes will argue for a mistrial and, if that is rejected, will ask Judge Philip Hickok to modify the jury's verdict and consider life without parole.
16_9ecbplus.58: The chance either argument will be successful is slight, Perlo said.
16_9ecbplus.59: But that then sets into motion the automatic appeals process, something that will be handled by a different set of attorneys.
16_9ecbplus.60: During that time, Orozco will not be housed with the general population, he will have a cell all his own giving him isolation from much of the gang violence in the state's prisons.
16_9ecbplus.61: At the very least, Perlo estimated the appeals process will last five years.
16_9ecbplus.62: It could run into 20 years because there are both state and federal requirements that must be met, he added.
16_9ecbplus.63: A large part of the problem stems from finding lawyers who are available for such a lengthy commitment of time, who are willing to take on a stressful job and who are qualified, Perlo said.
16_9ecbplus.64: "The decision today made the family happy, but unfortunately it's a false happiness, " Perlo said after court Tuesday.
16_9ecbplus.65: "I've dealt with issues of death for many years. ..
16_9ecbplus.66: the death penalty rarely offers. .. closure. "
16_9ecbplus.68: "I'm kind of relieved that it's over, " said 17 - year - old Jeremy Ortiz, one of the deputy's sons from a previous marriage.
16_9ecbplus.69: "I'm happy with the verdict, we just have to wait it out now. "
16_9ecbplus.70: Prior to the reading of the verdict, the deputy's family and friends waited in a courtroom filled to capacity but so quiet one could could hear the slight squeaks of the attorneys' leather chairs.
16_9ecbplus.71: Some bowed their heads and rubbed their faces, while others clasped their hands as though in prayer.
16_9ecbplus.72: When the sentence was finally announced a collective gasp for air was followed by cries and sobs as relatives sitting behind the family leaned forward to rub their shoulders and give a comforting squeeze.
16_9ecbplus.73: Outside the courtroom, Rosa Ortiz took out a button with a laminated picture of her slain son in uniform and handed it to the eldest of her five children, Art Ortiz, so that he could pin it on her blouse.
16_9ecbplus.74: Once it was secure she kissed it tenderly.
16_9ecbplus.75: For many minutes afterward, relatives and friends stood outside the courtroom hugging and crying.
16_9ecbplus.76: Detective Dawn Retzlaff, one of the two lead homicide detectives on the case, said authorities were grateful for the jury's thorough and careful review of the facts and investigators were happy with the verdict, calling it just.
16_9ecbplus.77: Speaking on behalf of the Sheriff's Department, Retzlaff added that they wanted to express their condolences to Ortiz's family in what was a devastating time.
16_9ecbplus.78: "It's not a happy day for anybody, " said Deputy District Attorney Lowell Anger, who prosecuted the case along with fellow DA Phillip Stirling.
16_9ecbplus.79: Anger said that the message sent by the jury's sentence - that killing a police officer and flaunting all respect for authority and for life will not be tolerated - was clear.
16_9ecbplus.80: It was the constant support from Anger, Stirling and the District Attorney's office, from the Sheriff's Department and other law enforcement agencies, and from the family's large circle of friends that made the tumultuous trial more bearable, Chela and her in - laws insisted.
16_9ecbplus.81: "We could never repay them for all the support and love they have for this family, and that they have for Jerry, " Chela said.

2_6ecbplus.0: Ellen DeGeneres to Host Next Year ’ s Oscars
2_6ecbplus.2: Reaching back to television for a comedy star, the producers of the Academy Awards telecast announced Friday that Ellen DeGeneres would return next year to host the annual Oscar ceremony.
2_6ecbplus.3: The producers, Craig Zadan and Neil Meron, caused some backlash last year after giving the job to Seth MacFarlane, the creator of the “ Family Guy ” animated show on the Fox network.
2_6ecbplus.4: Ms. DeGeneres has even less to do with the theatrical movie business than Mr. MacFarlane does ( his movie “ Ted ” preceded his appearance ) but she is well liked in Hollywood and her performance as the host of the show in 2007 was widely praised.
2_6ecbplus.5: In typical fashion, she released a jokey response to the honor: “ I am so excited to be hosting the Oscars for the second time.
2_6ecbplus.6: You know what they say — the third time ’ s the charm. ”

10_1ecbplus.0: Red Sox extend offer to Teixeira
10_1ecbplus.1: Boston reportedly looks to ink free - agent slugger for eight years
10_1ecbplus.3: Though the Red Sox continue to operate in intriguing secrecy when it comes to their pursuit of free - agent slugger Mark Teixeira, it appears an offer has been transmitted from the offices of 4 Yawkey Way in Boston to the corporation of power agent Scott Boras in Southern California.
10_1ecbplus.4: The Boston Herald reported in its Tuesday editions that the Red Sox have extended an offer for Teixeira, believed to be the longest and richest in the seven - year history of the ownership group led by John W. Henry.
10_1ecbplus.5: Though the newspaper doesn't cite its source, it stated that the offer is "believed to be for at least eight years. "
10_1ecbplus.6: The Red Sox have a club policy of not commenting on their negotiating stance with any free agents.
10_1ecbplus.7: Last week at the Winter Meetings, the Washington Nationals made Teixeira an eight - year, $160 million offer.
10_1ecbplus.8: Angels general manager Tony Reagins recently confirmed that his club had also made an eight - year offer.
10_1ecbplus.9: The Orioles, according to reports, have offered Teixeira a seven - year deal worth between $140 million and $150 million.
10_1ecbplus.10: As for the Red Sox, GM Theo Epstein hasn't so much as uttered Teixeira's name in any interviews with media members this offseason.
10_1ecbplus.11: That has always been the way Epstein conducts his business, and it's why you won't hear any public comments from the Red Sox regarding Teixeira until he either signs with Boston or goes somewhere else.
10_1ecbplus.12: "We're being aggressive, really aggressive on players that we like, " Epstein said last week.
10_1ecbplus.13: The two biggest investments the Red Sox have made under current ownership?
10_1ecbplus.14: A $103. 1 million sum - - including the $51. 1 million posting fee - - to Daisuke Matsuzaka over six seasons and a five - year, $70 million contract for J. D. Drew.
10_1ecbplus.15: Though breaking the bank in free agency isn't typically the way the Red Sox go about their Hot Stove business, they feel that Teixeira - - who will turn 29 in April - - could be the centerpiece of their lineup for the better part of a decade.
10_1ecbplus.16: The switch - hitter does everything the Red Sox like, from getting on base to hitting for power to playing terrific defense at first base.
10_1ecbplus.17: Epstein was asked at the Winter Meetings if the Red Sox could sign a marquee free agent this winter.
10_1ecbplus.18: "I think there's a chance of it, " he said.
10_1ecbplus.19: "There's definitely a chance that we don't.
10_1ecbplus.20: I can't tell you which [ answer ], eight, 10, 12 years from now would have been better for the organization.
10_1ecbplus.21: But players that we like and think can help us, we're going to try to sign to numbers that we think are reasonable and help us going forward and help us with our foundation.
10_1ecbplus.23: If we don't, then we'll move on. "
10_1ecbplus.24: The Yankees, Boston's top rival, have already made a loud statement this winter, agreeing to terms with starters CC Sabathia and A. J. Burnett.
10_1ecbplus.25: Though Epstein never likes to act as if he is counteracting the Yankees, Teixeira would clearly give Boston's lineup a more dynamic look.
10_1ecbplus.26: There have been conflicting reports as to whether the Yankees have interest in Teixeira.
10_1ecbplus.27: When Boras spoke at the Winter Meetings, he didn't sound as if he was in any rush to close the Teixeira deal.
10_1ecbplus.28: Back in November, while attending a Georgia Tech football game, Teixeira told ESPN that he'd like to sign by Christmas.
10_1ecbplus.29: If the Red Sox are successful in landing Teixeira, it will create a somewhat sticky situation.
10_1ecbplus.30: The Red Sox have Kevin Youkilis at first base and Mike Lowell at third.
10_1ecbplus.31: To open a spot for Teixeira, the Red Sox might have to trade Lowell and move Youkilis across the diamond.
10_1ecbplus.32: However, Lowell, coming off right hip surgery, is likely to have to prove his health in Spring Training if he is to be dealt.
10_1ecbplus.33: Last winter the Red Sox re - signed Lowell, the Most Valuable Player of the 2007 World Series, to a three - year, $37. 5 million contract.
10_1ecbplus.34: The Red Sox control Youkilis contractually for the next two years, so it's highly doubtful he would be moved.
10_1ecbplus.35: Youkilis finished third in the American League Most Valuable Player voting in November.
10_1ecbplus.36: David Ortiz, Boston's star designated hitter, is a 10 - 5 man ( 10 years in the Majors, five with the same team ), meaning he could veto any trade.

4_2ecbplus.0: Hollywood's Mermaid, Esther Williams dies at 91
4_2ecbplus.2: Esther Williams, whose experiences as a young swimming champion led to a career of Hollywood "aqua - musicals" designed just for her, died on Thursday in Beverly Hills, California, at the age of 91, her spokesman said.
4_2ecbplus.3: Williams, one of the biggest box - office stars of the 1940s and 1950s, died peacefully in her sleep and had been in declining health due to old age, spokesman Harlan Boll said.
4_2ecbplus.4: It was the pool - and wartime pinup pictures of her in bathing suits - that made her popular.

7_2ecbplus.0: Wladimir Klitschko retains titles stopping Thompson in six rounds
7_2ecbplus.3: Wladimir Klitschko stopped Tony Thompson in the sixth round to retain his WBA, IBF and WBO heavyweight title belts on Saturday.
7_2ecbplus.4: Klitschko put Thompson on the canvas with a big right hand near the end of the fifth round at Stade de Suisse, and the 40 - year - old American never recovered.
7_2ecbplus.5: The Ukrainian champion dropped Thompson again in the sixth, and referee Sam Williams gave the challenger a standing count before stopping the fight.
7_2ecbplus.6: Klitschko finished the fight five rounds sooner than when knocking out Thompson in the 11th of their first title fight in 2008.
7_2ecbplus.7: The 36 - year - old champion Klitschko improved to 58 - 3 ( 51 KO ).
7_2ecbplus.8: Thompson, who was the mandatory challenger nominated by the IBF, fell to 36 - 3 ( 24 KO ).

38_3ecbplus.2: Lake County's Cobb Mountain community was shaken awake early Thursday morning by a magnitude 4. 6 earthquake that startled even folks accustomed to seismic activity because of its size.
38_3ecbplus.3: While shakers around magnitude 2 and 3 are common to the area, Thursday's 2: 09 a. m. jolt lasted longer and proved stronger than usual, residents said.
38_3ecbplus.5: You could tell" it was larger, said Hardester's Market clerk Alicia Mullin.
38_3ecbplus.6: "It was pretty significant, " said Bonnie Evans at the Texaco station in town, where cigarettes, canned soups and a couple of bottles in the walk - in fridge had been knocked to the ground.
38_3ecbplus.7: The U. S. Geological Survey reported that the quake was centered about 3 miles southwest of Cobb, in a seismically active area near The Geysers geothermal steamfields.
38_3ecbplus.8: Residents of Sonoma County felt it, too, including some as far south as Santa Rosa.

41_8ecbplus.0: Sudan Bombs South Sudanese Refugee Camp, Reports Say
41_8ecbplus.2: Military aircraft from Sudan crossed the new international border with South Sudan and dropped bombs Thursday in and around a camp filled with refugees, officials said.
41_8ecbplus.3: A government official initially reported deaths, but an American activist who spoke to aid workers at the camp later said there were no casualties.
41_8ecbplus.4: There was no immediate comment from the Sudanese government in Khartoum on Thursday, as deadly fighting broke out in the Sudanese state of South Kordofan between the military and forces loyal to South Sudan, according to official Sudanese media.
41_8ecbplus.5: Meanwhile, the violence in and near the Yida refugee camp, located 10 miles ( 15 kilometers ) south of the border, came one day after bombings were reported in another region of South Sudan, an attack that provoked strong condemnation from the U. S. State Department.
41_8ecbplus.6: The president of South Sudan, which became the world's newest country only four months ago, said he fears the Khartoum - based government intends to invade the south soon.
41_8ecbplus.7: "Whatever allegations Khartoum labels against the Republic of South Sudan are baseless, but intended to justify his pending invasion of the south, " President Salva Kiir said.
41_8ecbplus.8: He later added: "We are committed to peaceful resolutions to any conflict but we will never allow our sovereignty to be violated by anybody. "
41_8ecbplus.9: The violence is especially troubling given the history between the two sides: The black African tribes of South Sudan and the mainly Arab north battled two civil wars over more than five decades, and some 2 million died in the latest war, from 1983 - 2005.
41_8ecbplus.10: A peace deal ended the war and South Sudan became its own country in July after a successful independence referendum.
41_8ecbplus.11: But there have been lingering disputes over border demarcation and oil - sharing revenues.
41_8ecbplus.12: Ryan Boyette, a former aid worker who lives in Sudan who is now leading a team of 15 citizen journalists, said he talked to five aid workers in the Yida camp, all of whom said that four bombs were dropped but that they caused no casualties.
41_8ecbplus.13: Boyette said a U. N. helicopter had landed on a nearby airstrip right as the first bomb hit.
41_8ecbplus.14: One of the bombs landed in a school yard where about 300 students were attending class, but the bomb did not explode, Boyette said, citing aid workers at the camp.
41_8ecbplus.15: Aleem Siddique, a U. N. spokesman in South Sudan, said: "We're concerned for the safety of civilians in the area following reports of explosions and we are liaising with the authorities. "
41_8ecbplus.16: Jonathan Hutson, a spokesman for the U. S. advocacy group the Enough Project, said aid workers inside the Yida refugee camp said at least one bomb landed in the camp, and three or four fell outside it.
41_8ecbplus.17: The aid workers or their groups could not be named for security reasons, Hutson said.
41_8ecbplus.18: Hutson said at least 15, 000 refugees who fled violence in Sudan are living in the Yida camp.
41_8ecbplus.19: They walked at least seven days to reach the camp, he said.
41_8ecbplus.20: Miabek Lang, the commissioner of Pariang County in South Sudan's Unity State, said earlier that 12 people were killed and 20 were wounded in Thursday's bombing.
41_8ecbplus.21: Lang could not be reached again for clarification on the conflicting reports.
41_8ecbplus.22: The Wednesday bombings in Upper Nile state sparked condemnation from the U. S. State Department, which said the "unacceptable and unjustified" attacks increase the potential of conflict between Sudan and South Sudan.
41_8ecbplus.23: South Sudan's president said Thursday that seven people were killed in those bombings.
41_8ecbplus.24: John Prendergast, the co - founder of the Enough Project, said the regime in Khartoum, Sudan's capital, is attempting to provoke South Sudan into restarting a war.
41_8ecbplus.25: "The regime's end game is to either capture South Sudan's oil fields along their common border, or achieve a stronger negotiating position on shared oil revenues and border demarcation, " Prendergast said.
41_8ecbplus.26: "This provocation must be countered by the full force of the international community, or else a massive war could unfold. "
41_8ecbplus.27: South Sudan's oil reserves must be pumped through pipelines that run through Sudan.
41_8ecbplus.28: Splitting the oil revenues has long been a major sticking point between the two sides.
41_8ecbplus.29: Another major issue is the demarcation of the border.
41_8ecbplus.30: Though the countries are now separate an official border has not yet been laid down.
41_8ecbplus.31: Sudan has accused South Sudan of arming pro - South Sudan groups in its territory.
41_8ecbplus.32: But Kiir said Thursday that the accusations from Khartoum are "smoke screens" to mask Sudan's support of armed groups fighting a proxy war against South Sudan.
41_8ecbplus.33: His comments came as Sudan said an unspecified number of rebels, soldiers and civilians were killed in clashes in the border state of South Kordofan in the town of Talodi on Thursday.
41_8ecbplus.34: Sudanese Army spokesman Khaled Saad, quoted in the official news agency SUNA, said the military had repelled a planned attack by forces loyal to the southern movement, or Sudan People's Liberation Army, who hail from a minority ethnic group now in control of much of South Sudan.

28_5ecbplus.0: Frederick LaRue, 75; Had Key Role in Coverup of the Watergate Break - In
28_5ecbplus.2: Frederick C. LaRue, a Mississippi oil heir who became the first person found guilty of participating in the Watergate coverup and was among those rumored to be the mysterious Deep Throat, has died at 75.
28_5ecbplus.3: LaRue's body was found Tuesday by a maid at the Biloxi hotel where he was staying.
28_5ecbplus.4: The Harrison County, Miss. , coroner, Gary Hargrove, told the Associated Press that LaRue is believed to have died Saturday of natural causes.
28_5ecbplus.5: A close friend and associate of John Mitchell - - President Nixon's attorney general and later his reelection campaign director - - LaRue became a trusted member of the administration in 1969, even though he did not have a salary, a title or a listing in the White House directory.
28_5ecbplus.6: Described as a skillful behind - the - scenes operator, he was present at a key meeting in 1972 between Mitchell and Nixon aide Jeb Stuart Magruder when the plan to break into the Democratic National Committee headquarters at the Watergate complex in Washington allegedly was approved.
28_5ecbplus.7: LaRue became a central figure in the Watergate coverup as the "bagman" who delivered hush money to participants in the bungled break - in.
28_5ecbplus.8: On June 27, 1973, he pleaded guilty to one charge of conspiring to obstruct justice and began cooperating with prosecutors.
28_5ecbplus.9: He served five months in federal prison.
28_5ecbplus.10: He remained an ardent defender of Nixon, speaking out as recently as last year to assail Magruder's assertions in a PBS program that the president ordered the illegal entry and bugging at the Watergate.
28_5ecbplus.11: LaRue had experienced scandal and tragedy before he ever entered Nixon's inner circle.
28_5ecbplus.12: His father, Ike Parsons LaRue, had served jail time for banking violations.
28_5ecbplus.13: Later, in 1954, he struck oil in Mississippi.
28_5ecbplus.14: Young Frederick worked in the oil field alongside other relatives for several years, until it was sold for a reported $30 million in 1967.
28_5ecbplus.15: That same year he shot and killed his father in a hunting accident in Canada.
28_5ecbplus.16: Various reports suggest that the LaRues never had control of the oil fortune or that they squandered it in bad investments.
28_5ecbplus.17: When Frederick LaRue's name started appearing in newspapers in connection with the Watergate controversy, he told a reporter that he was "no millionaire. "
28_5ecbplus.18: The family wealth, however, established him as a power in Mississippi politics in the 1960s.
28_5ecbplus.19: He was a major contributor to Arizona Republican Sen. Barry Goldwater's failed 1964 presidential bid.
28_5ecbplus.20: In 1967 LaRue became a generous friend of the Nixon campaign.
28_5ecbplus.21: When the Republican National Convention came around the following year, he was a key Southern strategist in the Nixon election drive.
28_5ecbplus.22: In 1972, after Mitchell resigned as attorney general to head the Committee to Re - Elect the President, known as CREEP, LaRue became a hard - core member of the "Mitchell group" at CREEP, along with Robert C. Mardian and Henry S. Fleming.
28_5ecbplus.23: He also worked closely with Magruder, the deputy campaign manager.
28_5ecbplus.24: They became so close that they were often referred to as one person, "Magrue. "
28_5ecbplus.25: LaRue was with Magruder, Mitchell and Mardian at a campaign stop in Los Angeles when the Watergate burglars were arrested, on June 17, 1972.
28_5ecbplus.26: G. Gordon Liddy, one of "the plumbers" - - the nickname for the clandestine White House operation that carried out the burglary - - phoned Magruder and LaRue during breakfast to break the news.
28_5ecbplus.29: He wants me to go out to some air base and talk on a secure phone, ' " LaRue, recalling Magruder's words, told the Biloxi Sun Herald last year.
28_5ecbplus.30: "I said, 'Go get the damned pay phone.
28_5ecbplus.31: That's just as good, and find out what he wants. ' "
28_5ecbplus.32: According to Magruder's testimony before the Senate Watergate committee - - an account reportedly confirmed by LaRue - - he and LaRue worked in lock - step with Mitchell and Mardian from that day forward to concoct and maintain a coverup story.
28_5ecbplus.33: "I joined in that coverup, at least by acquiescence, " LaRue said in a statement after he admitted the government's charges against him.
28_5ecbplus.34: He also joined Mardian in destroying documents and financial records pertaining to the Watergate operation.
28_5ecbplus.35: Additionally, LaRue received more than $300, 000 in cash, which he distributed to Watergate defendants and their lawyers.
28_5ecbplus.36: James W. McCord Jr. , one of the men arrested at the Watergate complex, said at the time that the money was paid to ensure that all the defendants would plead guilty and remain silent.
28_5ecbplus.37: Of the seven defendants, McCord and Liddy refused to plead guilty, but all were found guilty of conspiracy, burglary and wiretapping.
28_5ecbplus.38: Although the first to plead guilty in the coverup case, LaRue was the last defendant to be sentenced.
28_5ecbplus.39: He served most of a six - month sentence before returning to Mississippi.
28_5ecbplus.40: He was often mentioned as among those thought to be Washington Post reporter Bob Woodward's shadowy inside source, Deep Throat.
28_5ecbplus.41: Other candidates included Alexander Haig, Nixon's chief of staff and later President Reagan's secretary of State; Earl J. Silbert, an original Watergate prosecutor; and L. Patrick Gray, the acting FBI director, who lived near Woodward.
28_5ecbplus.42: LaRue denied the distinction, as did all the others, and conjectured that the legendary source was actually an amalgamation of figures close to the scandal.
28_5ecbplus.43: "Who. .. would it have been? " he mused in an interview with a Biloxi reporter recently.
28_5ecbplus.44: "There were not that many people who knew the inside and out of what was going on.
28_5ecbplus.45: I don't think it would have been Magruder.
28_5ecbplus.47: Woodward, who said he would reveal Deep Throat's identity after the source died, could not be reached Wednesday.

31_11ecbplus.0: Creighton defeats Drake 65 - 53 in MVC tournament
